main_definition: (with a possessive pronoun) Everything that one is capable of.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (with a possessive pronoun) Everything that one is capable of.
meanings_and_examples.example: She gave her all, and collapsed at the finish line.
When going through a divorce, she had to divide 'all' her assets with her ex-husband.
I want all the cookies on the plate, not just a few.
The score was 30 all when the rain delay started.
Don't want to go? All the better since I lost the tickets.
I'll be there all weekend, even if it means sacrificing my plans.
She knows all and sees all.
A good time was had by all.
All that was left was a small pile of ash.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Used after who, what, where, how and similar words, either without changing their meaning, or indicating that one expects that they cover more than one element, e.g. that "who all attended" is more than one person. (Some dialects only allow this to follow some words and not others.)
meanings_and_examples.example: Several friends from different parts of the city all attended the surprise party.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Clipping of y’all. Used only as a vocative.
meanings_and_examples.example: Hey all, how’s everyone doing today?
All the hard work I put into my studies, although it didn't guarantee me a top grade.
